awd_titl_txt: BTT EAGER:  A system for the production of haploid inducer lines and cytoplasmic male sterile doubled haploids for efficient hybrid production
awd_abstract_narration:
Hybrid cultivars are a cornerstone of modern crop production. Seed companies spend many years developing elite, inbred parental lines that are used to produce the hybrid seed that farmers plant each season. A major bottleneck in the plant breeding cycle is caused by the fact that it takes many years to produce these inbred parental lines.  The aim of this project is to develop a shortcut that allows inbred parental lines to be produced in a single year.  To accomplish this goal, the investigators plan to use gene editing techniques to generate novel onion plants that greatly accelerate the process of inbred line development.  The strategy deployed in this work should also be broadly applicable to other crops, making it of general use to the plant breeding community. This work will be carried out in collaboration with Dr. Stephen Jackson at the University of Warwick.

The investigators will use CRISPR/Cas9 methods to introduce genetic variation into the CENH3 gene of onion in order to produce haploid-inducer lines. A haploid-inducer line is a plant from which a significant fraction of the seed produced by cross-pollination is haploid.  Upon chemically-induced chromosome doubling, these haploid progeny become "instant inbred" lines that can be immediately used for hybrid seed production.  The research team at the University of Wisconsin will use T-DNA transformation and particle bombardment methods to deliver the gene editing reagents into onion somatic embryos, while the group at the University of Warwick will use tobacco rattle virus (TRV) expression vectors.  Deploying a variety of gene-editing strategies in parallel should allow the investigators to quickly determine which approach is the most effective for efficiently producing modified CENH3 alleles.  In order for doubled haploid technology to be commercially useful for hybrid seed production, it is essential that the strategies for producing doubled haploids are compatible with cytoplasmic male sterile breeding systems. For this reason, this project will integrate the production of haploid inducer lines within a cytoplasmic male sterile breeding framework in order to maximize the practical benefit and applicability to breeders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this research project was to develop a haploid inducer line for onion by using gene editing techniques to introduce mutations into the centromeric histone 3 (CENH3) gene of onion.  A haploid inducer is a mutant plant that plant breeders can use to produce “doubled haploids”.  In the case of a diploid species like onion, a haploid plant is one that only carriers a single copy of each chromosome.  A doubled haploid is a plant that started out as a haploid early in development, but then underwent a doubling of the number of chromosomes in its cells. Scientists have developed straightforward protocols for converting haploid plants into doubled haploids. A doubled haploid has two copies of every chromosome, but for each chromosome pair the DNA sequences are identical.  In the field of plant breeding, the ability to produce plants with the diploid number of chromosomes in which both copies of the chromosomes are genetically identical is of great practical value.  Specifically, doubled haploids form the basis for the production of hybrid crops. 

For many crop species, haploid inducer lines do not exist.  Past work with the plant model species Arabidopsis thaliana has shown how mutating CENH3 can lead to a haploid inducer phenotype. The aim of this project was therefore to determine if mutations in CENH3 in onion could produce this haploid inducer phenotype.

The first challenge of this project was to introduce targeted mutations into the CENH3 gene of onion.  We tested a number of different strategies for producing gene edited onion plants, but unfortunately none of those experiments led to the regeneration of gene edited onion plants with mutations in the CENH3 gene.  For this reason, we were not able to test the role of CENH3 mutations on haploid induction in onion.  However, we did make significant progress in the development of gene editing techniques for onion, including the development of an efficient protocol for testing gene editing efficiency in onion, efficient protocols for regenerating onion plants from immature embryos, and efficient transient gene editing in immature onion cells.  We hope to build upon these preliminary successes in the near future to produce onion plants with CENH3 mutations so that we can test the effect that these mutations have on haploid induction.

This project provided training and professional development opportunities for three postdoctoral scientists, a research technician, and a graduate student.


Last Modified: 07/04/2023
Modified by: Patrick J Krysan
